claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, causing no harm.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, causing no harm.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large quantities over a short period.
Gum may contain artificial sweeteners or additives that could cause digestive discomfort in sensitive individuals.
Most gum additives are approved as safe for consumption and are present in quantities too small to cause harm.

supporting.text: Swallowing gum occasionally does not lead to any known medical complications.

attacks.text: Swallowing gum occasionally does not lead to any known medical complications.
Swallowing large amounts of gum frequently can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Most people do not swallow large amounts of gum frequently, so the risk of intestinal blockage is minimal.
Gum is indigestible and can accumulate in the digestive tract over time, potentially causing issues.
The human digestive system can pass indigestible materials like gum without issues in normal quantities.

supporting.text: The human digestive system cannot break down the synthetic components of gum, so it is excreted unchanged.

attacks.text: The human digestive system cannot break down the synthetic components of gum, so it is excreted unchanged.
While gum is not digested, swallowing large amounts can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large quantities.
Some synthetic components in gum may interact with gut bacteria, potentially causing minor digestive discomfort.
Gut bacteria interactions with gum components are not well-documented and likely negligible for most people.

supporting.text: There is no scientific evidence that swallowing gum causes intestinal blockages or other health issues.

attacks.text: There is no scientific evidence that swallowing gum causes intestinal blockages or other health issues.
While rare, documented cases exist where swallowed gum contributed to intestinal blockages, especially in children or when combined with other indigestible materials.
The rarity of such cases suggests they are statistically insignificant compared to the vast number of people who swallow gum without issues.
Gum is indigestible and may accumulate in the digestive tract over time, increasing the risk of blockages with frequent swallowing.
The human digestive system can typically pass indigestible materials like gum without issue, as per gastroenterological studies.

supporting.text: Medical consensus holds that swallowing gum is harmless unless done in extremely large quantities.

attacks.text: Medical consensus holds that swallowing gum is harmless unless done in extremely large quantities.
Swallowing gum can lead to gastrointestinal blockages, especially in children, even in small quantities.
Cases of gum causing blockages are extremely rare and usually involve pre-existing digestive issues.
Gum contains indigestible synthetic polymers that may accumulate in the digestive tract over time.
The human digestive system is capable of passing small amounts of indigestible materials without issue.

supporting.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach, contrary to popular myths.

attacks.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach, contrary to popular myths.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Most people swallow gum occasionally without any issues, making blockages extremely rare.
Gum contains indigestible synthetic polymers that may accumulate in the digestive tract over time.
The human digestive system can pass small amounts of indigestible materials like gum without issues.
